He replied:
It is so!
It is so!
After the monks heard this, they went to inform the World-Honored One:
How much offense did this scolding woman obtain?
The Buddha said:
She obtained much offense.
The bhiká¹£us asked again:
How many is considered a lot?
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
This woman will always be born as a one-eyed crow for five hundred lifetimes, and in all her rebirths she will die of starvation.
The Buddha said:
Call Aniruddha.
Having called him, the Buddha asked Aniruddha:
Is it really so?
He replied:
It is really so.
The Buddha told Aniruddha:
Although you wish to have few affairs, from today onwards it is not permitted to take with one's own hands.

Furthermore, the Buddha was staying at ÅšrÄvastÄ«. At that time, the World-Honored One prohibited taking with one's own hands. The bhiká¹£us, having heard this, received water and toothbrushes from others. Those who had attendants could obtain them, but those who did not have attendants suffered and could not obtain them.

At that time, the World-Honored One was expounding the Dharma for the great assembly. A bhiká¹£u smelled a foul odor from his own mouth. He sat downwind from the others, not wanting the foul odor from his mouth to affect the pure practitioners.
The Buddha knew this and deliberately asked:
Why is the bhiká¹£u sitting there?
Like someone with anger and resentment.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
The World-Honored One has established the precept that one cannot take without being given. The bhiká¹£us all receive water and toothpicks from others.
If there is a pure person, one can get them. If there is no pure person, it is difficult to get them. Fearing that the foul odor from the mouth will affect the pure practitioners, they sit downwind.
The Buddha said:
From today, I allow the exception of water and toothpicks.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
All those who reside in ÅšrÄvastÄ« should gather. For ten reasons, I establish precepts for the bhiká¹£us. Those who have already heard it should listen again.
If a bhiká¹£u takes what is not given and puts it in his mouth, except for water and tooth cleaners, it is pÄyattika.
Bhiká¹£u is as explained above.
Not given means not given by others, not received from a previous person. Putting food in the mouth, except for water and tooth cleaners.
There are ten kinds of water, as explained above. If the water is turbid, it should be received.
If the water is naturally yellow, drinking it is not an offense.
Tooth cleaners are of two kinds:
one is split, the other is a ball.
If a bhiká¹£u has a sore in his mouth caused by hot air, the doctor says:
You should chew a tooth cleaner and swallow the juice.
One should receive it.
Except for water and tooth cleaners, the World-Honored One says there is no offense.
PÄyattika is as explained above.
On food, on a tree, in a well, on a roof, in a clean kitchen, receiving in a vessel, receiving in a non-vessel, bed, boat, vehicle, mental reception, on a road.

On top of food means if, when eating, one spreads a bed, a long board, a bundle of sugarcane, a bundle of radishes, or a bag of grains or beans on top, and spreads various sitting mats and covers on top.
When a bhiká¹£u is sitting, he should not move his body or ask questions.
If he moves or asks:
What is this?
This is called impure.
If, when a bhiká¹£u is eating, wind blows dust down onto the bowl, but it does not contaminate the food, he may eat it. The grass leaves should be received.
If it contaminates the grass leaves and the food, all should be received again.
When a bhiká¹£u is eating, if dust from the feet of cows, camels, and so forth comes down and contaminates it, but it does not contaminate the food, he may eat it.
If it contaminates the grass leaves, they should be received again.
If it contaminates the grass leaves and the food, all should be received again.
If dust from the shaking of an animal's body comes down, if one intentionally receives it, it is called received.
If dust from a flock of birds comes down, it is the same.
If a bhiká¹£u is eating and a woman passes by dragging her clothes on the ground, dust will also rise up and cover him, it is the same as this.
If a pure person is passing grass leaves, the bhiká¹£u should say:
Let go.
If passing salt, fruits, or vegetables, he should say:
Let go.
If a pure person is passing fruits and they fall onto the grass, and he immediately moves away, it is not considered received.
If he pauses for a short while, it is considered received.
If the fruit is hard, he may pick it up and wash it to eat. If it is rotten, he should not pick it up.
If a pure person is passing flour and shakes the flour container, and flour falls into the container, if he intends to receive it, it is considered received.
If he does not intend to receive it, he should receive it again.
If a pure person is carrying a container of flour and the container falls into the bhiká¹£u's bowl, if he immediately pushes it away when it falls, the container is still considered pure.
If he pauses for a while, it is considered impure.
If it is a copper vessel, it should be washed and used after purification.
If the oil penetrates into the wooden vessel, it should be discarded.
If the oil does not penetrate, it can be scraped and used.
When serving rice, if rice grains jump into the air and land in the bowl, if the bhiká¹£u has the intention to receive it, it is considered received.
If he does not have the intention to receive it, he should receive it again.
Serving ghee, milk, curd, meat, vegetables, sauces, etc. is also like this.

If a five-year great assembly is held, on the Buddha's birthday, the day he attained enlightenment, the day he turned the Dharma wheel, on the great assembly day of Ä€nanda, the great assembly day of RÄhula, if it is difficult to obtain a pure person, the bhiká¹£us should go to the vegetable pile to receive vegetables, and serve salt, flour, and rice in the same way.
If the pure person lifts it off the ground, it is also considered received, but it is not proper deportment.
The bhiká¹£u should tell the pure person:
You lift it off the ground and give it to me.
If the pure person is small and cannot lift it, he should say:
You distribute it to me little by little.
The same applies when receiving soup, pastries, and other food and drink.
If receiving a ghee jar and the rope is on the ground, one should say:
Lift this rope.
If the attendant is small and cannot lift it, one should instruct:

In this way, if the cauldron or pot is hot and one cannot receive it, one should place two pieces of wood horizontally on the ground, step on them with one's feet, and say:ğŸ”½Receive!
Receive!
This is called on the food.
As for on a tree, if an attendant is eating fruit on a tree and a bhiká¹£u says:
Give me some fruit.
If the attendant shakes the tree and the fruit falls into the bhiká¹£u's container, it is considered received, but it is not proper conduct.
In this way, if one uses one's feet, hands, or mouth to pick the fruit, and the fruit touches the branches and leaves, the bhiká¹£u should generate the thought again and say:ğŸ”½Receive!ğŸ”½Receive!
It is considered received.
If it is tied with a rope and hangs down, whether it is the foot or the hand, when releasing the rope and letting it down, if it touches the branches and leaves, one should also say:ğŸ”½Accept!
Accept!
This is called acceptance.
If the pure person is eating flour and beans, and the bhiká¹£u wishes to obtain some, he immediately asks for it, saying:
Give me some flour and beans.
The pure person is unwilling to give, the bhiká¹£u pulls the pure person's hand, pours it into his robe, and says:ğŸ”½Accept!
Accept!
It is called acceptance, but it is not proper deportment.
If a monkey is eating fruit in a tree, and the bhiká¹£u wishes to obtain the fruit, he tells the monkey:
Give me the fruit.
The monkey shakes the tree, and the fruit falls down. The bhiká¹£u uses a vessel to catch it.
If it falls into the vessel, it is called acceptance, but it is not proper deportment.
In this way, if it is the hand, foot, or mouth, when the fruit falls down, if it rubs against the branches and leaves, one should generate the thought again and say:
Accept!
Receive it!
This is called receiving, and it is called on a tree.
As for in a well, if a bhiká¹£u lives in a secluded place, and the well is full of water, and there is no attendant,
the bhiká¹£u himself draws water from the well. Another bhiká¹£u says:

The bhiká¹£u in the well says:
If I come out, the water will fill up again.
I want to eat here, please lower the food down.
The attendant should put the food and drink in a container and tie a rope to it.
When it's time to eat, the bhiká¹£u at the bottom of the well should tell the attendant:

If there are living plants on the side of the well, he should tell them to avoid it.
After lowering it to the bottom of the well, the bhiká¹£u should pull the rope with one hand, hold it with the other hand, and say:ğŸ”½Receive it!
Receive it!
This is called receiving.
If the well water is clear, he may take it himself to drink.
If it is turbid, tell the pure person:
Take a new clean jar and tie a rope to the bottom of the jar.
As explained above, this is called a well.
As for on a roof, if a bhiká¹£u lives in a secluded place without a pure person, the bhiká¹£u himself covers the roof.
A bhiká¹£u tells the bhiká¹£u on the roof:
It's time to eat, come down to eat.
The bhiká¹£u says:
It's difficult to stop working and come down, I want to eat here, bring the food up.
Tell the pure person:

The bhiká¹£u lowers a long pole with a hook, and tells the pure person:

Say this:ğŸ”½Receive!
Receive!
This is called receiving.
Lowering a rope is also like this, this is called on a roof.

As for the clean kitchen, if a new monastery is being built, the kitchen should not be built in the east wing or north wing, but should be built in the south wing or west wing. The kitchen should be provided with ventilation, and the drainage should be connected to a drain for washing and cleaning.
In the kitchen, a cooking platform should be built.
When cooking, if the attendant is small, the bhiká¹£us may themselves wash the copper cauldrons and pots and fill them with water, and then tell the attendant:
You know how to wash the rice.
If the attendant is small and cannot do it, they may hold their hands and teach them how to wash and drain the rice.
If the dishes are uncovered, they should be told to cover them.
If there is no attendant, if there are clean mats, clean cloth, or clean boards, they may cover them themselves, but only by hanging them over the top.
When drying grain, if bhiká¹£us walk on the grain, they should have the attendant remove the trampled area.
If chased by a lion, tiger, or wolf, or if a woman is chasing with lustful intentions, a bhiká¹£u should abandon and run away, not looking back. Even if he steps on them, there is no offense.
If there is a heap of grain and it rains, one should have a pure person cover it.
If there is no pure person, one may throw a pure mat from a distance to cover it, or one may pick up a pure brick or stone and throw it to press down on it.

If a new monastery is being built, in the pure kitchen there are various things, such as pure oil, seven-day oil, flour bottles, lime bottles, salt bottles, sawdust bottles, molasses bottles, clay bottles, bundles of sugarcane, bundles of bamboo, bundles of dried meat, and bundles of tree bark, all in the pure room in one place. He says:ğŸ”½Bring a lime jar.

If the kitchen building is broken and leaking, he tells the caretaker:

The bhiká¹£u can stand in the center and point to the placement of milk, curd, ghee, oil, honey, molasses, and salt. One should not see the kitchen building damaged and not repaired. One should follow the Vinaya rules to deal with matters. This is called the kitchen building.
As for vessels and non-vessels, all leaves that are rolled up are vessels, and unfolded ones are non-vessels.

If a bed or sitting bed has tight weaving, it is a vessel, and if the weaving is loose, it is not a vessel.
A boat, in the water, is not a vessel, but on the shore, it is a vessel.
If a cart is yoked to an ox, it is not a vessel, but when there is no ox, it is a vessel.

If a bhiká¹£u is begging for food, and a shop owner fills a bushel measure with flour and gives it to the bhiká¹£u, with the bushels connected in tiers, either five, four, three, two, or one bushel connected, the bhiká¹£u should then say to the donor:

If the bushels cannot be untied, the bhiká¹£u should ask for leaves, have them poured onto the leaves to receive, this is called receiving with a vessel, not receiving with a vessel.
Receiving on a bed means if a bhiká¹£u is sitting, meditating, or sleeping on a bed, and a pure person brings food and places it in his lap, if he is aware, it is called receiving.
If he is not aware, when he wakes up and wants to eat, he should receive it again from the pure person.

If a bhiká¹£u has pure food or robes and alms bowl on a raised platform, when taking the robes and alms bowl, if he moves the pure objects, all become impure.

If a bhiká¹£u has ghee and oil jars on a robe rack, when the bhiká¹£u takes the robes, if they move, it is the same. This is called a bed.

As for a boat, if a boat is loaded with the seventeen kinds of grains, with mats spread on top of the grains, or with mats covering the top, a bhiká¹£u may sit on it, but he should not call it by name.
If he calls it by name, it is called impure.
If this boat is suddenly blown by the wind, or goes downstream, or the waves turn the boat and it drifts onto the shore, all become impure.
If the ropes or bamboo poles do not leave the water, it is pure. This is called a boat.

Vehicle means if seventeen kinds of grains are loaded on a large cart, and straw mats are spread on top of the grains, and a bhiká¹£u sits on top, he should not call it by name, calling it by name is impure.

When going down, the bhiká¹£u goes down first, and the pure person goes down later.
If it is going down a slope and the cart overturns and is separated from the ground and the oxen, all are impure.
If it is going down a slope, and the cart overturns, and the body of the oxen and the tail of the rope are not separated from the cart, all are pure. This is called a vehicle.
Mindful acceptance means there is a country called Dengqu, in the borderlands, where people have wrong views. Because of evil bhiká¹£us, they do not offer food.
At that time, when the food is about to fill the bowl, if a leaf falls into the bowl, one should make this statement from a distance:ğŸ”½Accept!
Accept!
If one is not aware when it falls into the bowl, it is considered accepted, but it is not proper conduct.
If one is aware when it falls, but not when it first enters the bowl, it is considered accepted, but it is not proper conduct.
If one is aware when it enters and when it falls into the bowl, it is considered a good acceptance.

If a bhiká¹£u is begging for food, and a piece of meat falls into his bowl from a crow or bird, if he is aware when it enters but not when it falls, it is considered accepted, but it is not proper conduct.

As for the road, if a bhiká¹£u wants to travel with merchants, he should tell the merchants:

If the provisions in the bag were exhausted and the journey was not yet over, he should untie the bag, wash it clean, obtain more provisions, put them in the bag, and tie it as before.

When they arrived, the ox was returned to its original owner.
If the monks were traveling along the road and passed by a sugarcane field,

Accept!

When a bhiká¹£u is traveling on the road, if he receives flour from a pure person, and the rope is not yet off the ground, it is considered received, but it is not proper deportment.
